This work aims to study the effect of different atmospheres and temperatures in the synthesis of a bifunctional electrocatalyst for ORR and OER reactions in the cathode of a Zn-air battery, using a carbonaceous support for dispersing Ni and Co species. At 300 °C, NiCo2O4 with a size of 4.93 nm under O2 and 150.14 nm using air, were obtained. These materials exhibited low specific surface area and pore volume and failed to show bifunctional activity. Instead, the simultaneous dispersion of NiO and CoO nanoparticles, with a size of 2.55 nm was achieved at 300 °C under N2 (NiCo/MC-N300), leading to a surface enrichment in Co2+ and Ni2+ species, while Ni and Co nanoparticles, 12.81 nm, were obtained at 700 °C under N2 (NiCo/MC-N700). These catalysts exhibited high specific surface area and pore volume, and bifunctional electrochemical activity; as well as high specific-capacity in a home-made Zn-air battery. Graphical Abstract Keywords Mesoporous carbon (MC) Metal oxide nanoparticles Oxygen evolution and reduction reactions Electrocatalysts Zn-air battery Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The energy transition is one of the major challenges for scientific, industrial, and political communities to contribute to significant decarbonization of our economy, mainly in the production chain, transportation systems, and energy production sectors, allowing access to affordable and clean energy for all. Nevertheless, the shift from non-renewable sources of energy such as oil, carbon, and natural gas to production chains and devices powered by renewable energy must be based on sustainability, equality, and social justice thus contributing to the Sustainable Development Objectives (SDO) program of the ONU [1]. The use of renewable sources of energy such as solar and wind requires the development of high-capacity and efficient energy storage systems with high cyclability and built-up with earth's abundant resources [2]. In this regard, metal-air batteries (MABs) represent a great opportunity for energy storage devices, as they offer high specific energy density [3,4]. The rechargeable Zn-air batteries (ZABs) are a promising, competitive, safe, low cost, and environmentally friendly MAB, with a high theoretical energy density (1350 W h kg−1), high specific capacity (820 mA h g−1) and stable discharge potential range from 1.2 to 1.4 V [5–9]. For these reasons the primary ZABs have been commercially used for some practical applications [10], and several companies are interested in its development as energy storage systems on the grid [11–15]. The ZABs devices are composed of three compartments: i) the Zn anode, where redox reactions of a metal take place, ii) a separator between the two electrodes that allows the flow of hydroxyl ions while blocking zincate ions and iii) the cathode, where oxygen reactions occur [7,16]. The reactions occurring during the discharge and charging processes in a ZBA are thermodynamically spontaneous, with a theoretical voltage of 1.66 V. Nevertheless, each of the structural components of a ZBA presents certain drawbacks. In real applications, the presence of CO2 is challenging because of the possible carbonation of CO2 in the alkaline electrolyte, thus modifying the cell environment. In addition, the CO2 can obstruct the pores of the gas diffusion layer (GLD), limiting the passage of O2 [12,15]. Regarding the separator, it is necessary to develop a selective material allowing the flow of hydroxyl ions while blocking the flow of zinc ions. In this way, is important to study the implementation of different types of electrolytes such as solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs), quasi-neutral electrolytes and non-aqueous electrolytes [17–19]. In the case of the metallic Zn anode, it is necessary to control the dissolution and non-uniform deposition of Zn in order to avoid the formation of dendrites [20] and the change in the surface of the metallic Zn [21]. In addition, it is necessary to avoid side reactions in the Zn anode, such as the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [12,15,22]. Finally, perhaps the most relevant challenge is the slow kinetics in the ORR and OER reactions, affecting the cyclability and power density in practical applications [12,15]. The operation of the cathode is based on two reactions that are of fundamental importance for the energy transition [2], and that might proceed through different mechanisms (Table S1), the Oxygen Reduction Reaction (ORR, Eq. 1) during discharging and the Oxygen Evolution Reaction (OER, Eq. 2) during the charging process [16,23–25]: (1) O 2 ( g ) + 2 H 2 O ( l ) + 4 e − ⇌ 4 OH ( aq ) − E o = 0.401 V vs . SHE , alkaline media (2) 4 OH ( aq ) − ⇌ O 2 ( g ) + 2 H 2 O ( l ) + 4 e − E o = 0.401 V vs . SHE , in alkaline media The sluggish kinetics of both reactions and low cyclability need to be overcome to achieve a commercial implementation of such kind of technology. Therefore, the use of a robust bifunctional electrocatalyst with activity for both reactions and obtain from abundant earth materials is of fundamental interest [5,7,8,26]. The challenge is to develop a catalyst with: i) high specific surface area and pore volume allowing high dispersion of active sites and accessibility of reactants to the active centers, ii) high conductivity for electron transfer, iii) proper adsorption and activation of O2 during ORR and OH- ions during OER, iv) stability under electrocatalytic reaction allowing high cyclability, and v) based on abundant earth elements avoiding the use of noble metals. In this way, heterogeneous electrocatalysts based on the use of carbonaceous supports for dispersing transition metals or metal oxides are among the most intensively studied nowadays [2,24,25]. Metal-free and doped carbonaceous materials as well as transition metal oxides (TMOs) are potential electrocatalytic materials for both reactions. Carbonaceous materials offer an unique opportunity for developing highly efficient electrocatalysts because of their physicochemical properties: high specific surface area allowing a high dispersion of the active sites, high pore volume allowing diffusion of active chemical species to and from the active sites, stability, electrical conductivity and cost-effective production processes [7,27,28]. Despite these advantages, these materials show some drawbacks such as high corrosion and poor electrocatalytic performance. For instance, in recent years research has focused in improving the structure and surface chemistry properties, and this is possible because carbonaceous materials can be obtained from a wide variety of chemical precursors and biomass-derived compounds, allowing a fine tuning of the microstructure and surface chemistry through doping with heteroatoms or dispersing transition metals even at atomic level thus leading to a wide variety of active electrocatalysts [7,29–31]. Significant efforts have been made to use biomass-derived carbonaceous materials, as an example Fe5C2 nanoparticles (NPs) were formed and entrapped in a Mn, N, S carbon nanotube by implementing a one-step pyrolysis of a mixture of lignin, metal precursors and dicyandiamide [32]. The obtained Fe5C2/Mn, N, S-CNTs material exhibited activity in ORR, with an onset potential, E onset, of 1.04 V and a high half-wave potential, E 1/2, of 0.85 V; the material was also evaluated in the cathode of a Zn-air battery showing high power density, 153.19 mW cm−2, and high cyclability. Single atom catalysts, especially those using carbonaceous materials as supports, have also attracted attention because of the low loading of active species and the high dispersion that can be achieved leading to high active electrocatalysts [29,33,34]. 2D Nb4C3Tx nanosheets with interfacial self-assembled Fe-N-C single-atom structures, Fe-N-C/Nb4C3Tx, exhibited electrocatalytic activity for ORR with an E 1/2 of 0.911 V, and OER with a η 10 of 1.52 V in the alkaline media [34]. On the other hand, TMOs exhibit multiple oxidation states, which is important in the activation of the intermediate species and transport of electrons. Among the most studied TMOs are NiO and spinel-like Co3O4; however, despite having high electrocatalytic performance for the OER and ORR, these TMOs exhibit some drawbacks, Co3O4 exhibits low electrical conductivity, whereas NiO, despite having good electrical conductivity and activity against OER, exhibits low activity for the ORR [35–37]. In this regard, the combination of nickel and cobalt species in the spinel-like NiCo2O4 oxide have demonstrated high catalytic activity attributed to improved dispersion of the active sites, Ni3+ and Co3+ for OER and Co2+ for ORR, and increased electrical conductivity, these materials exhibited high BET surface area and small NiCo2O4 particle size, properties that might be at the origin of the electrocatalytic activity as bifunctional electrocatalysts for ORR and OER reactions [38–42]. On the other hand, it has also been investigated the synergistic effect between NiCo oxides and different carbonaceous materials [40,43–46]. A material possessing a ternary heterointerface, NiCo2O4/NCNTs/NiCo, exhibited bifunctional electrocatalytic activity with an E1/2 of 0.83 V in ORR and a EJ10 of 1.58 V in OER, with notable stability up to 586 h when evaluated in a ZAB [44]. The electrocatalytic performance was attributed to the synergistic action of the three interfaces of the bimetallic centers and the carbon nanostructures doped with heteroatoms [44]. The successful synthesis of a NiCo alloy inserted in N-CNTs, NiCo@nNCNTs/HN, in which the carbon inhibited the corrosion of metals and the pore structure limited the growth and the aggregation of NiCo alloys [47], led to a bifunctional activity, this material exhibited an E1/2 of 0.87 V for ORR and displayed a low OER overpotential of 330 mV. NiCo alloy hollow spheres confined in a N-doped carbon, NiCo@N-C HS, produced a material with a hollow structure and the interaction of NiCo nanoparticles with N-doped C layer exposed more active sites thus facilitating a rapid diffusion of the O2 and the electrolyte, consequently promoting the activation of the O2* and OH* intermediates [48]. The material exhibited an E1/2 of 0.77 V (ORR) and an overpotential of 310 mV (n10, OER) with a high specific capacity of 788.7 mWh gZn −1, additionally the material exhibited stability for over 200 h when evaluated in a ZAB. The use of porous carbonaceous supports has shown that it can improve charge transfer and chemical stability, as well as provide a high surface area and pore volume to enhance the dispersion of a greater number of active sites that are more accessible for mass transport with a better diffusion of reagents and products [43,49]. However, the electrocatalytic activity towards OER and ORR demonstrates a strong dependence on porous structure, particle size, and chemistry at the surface which are all dependent mainly on the synthesis methodology [5,8,50,51]. Consequently, the physical and chemical properties mediating the interactions and surface contact between the active phase and the support result in different electrochemical properties that determine the performance of MABs, as an example, the combination of Ni/Fe atomically dispersed on a N-doped carbonaceous support demonstrated activity for ORR while nanoparticles of Ni/Fe exhibited activity for OER [52]. Therefore, expanding the research on the arrangement of the metallic active sites on the support, mediated through modification in the synthesis methodology to achieve a fine tuning of the physicochemical properties and in this way, enhancing the electrocatalytic performance towards OER and ORR, is of vital importance at a scientific level. In this work, the purpose was to prepare a porous carbonaceous material as support to simultaneously disperse Ni- and Co-oxides, by using different temperatures and atmospheres during the thermal transformation of the metal precursors into their oxides, with the aim to control i) the chemical composition and structure, ii) the particle size and localization, and iii) the stability upon cycling. The hypothesis was that the simultaneous confinement inside the mesopore structure of a carbonaceous support of fine-tunned metal oxide particles of nickel and cobalt lead to a bifunctional electrocatalyst for ORR and OER reactions with high cyclability. Additionally, the electrocatalysts that showed the best activity for these reactions were evaluated in the cathode of a rechargeable Zn-air home made battery. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials All chemicals were used as received. The non-ionic copolymer triblock surfactant PEO132PPO50PEO132 (F108, MW = 14600) and resorcinol (99 %) were provided by Sigma–Aldrich Chemical Co. Sodium Hydroxide (98%) and Formaldehyde solution (37 %) were provided by PanReac AppliChem. Tretraethoxysilane (TEOS, 98 %), nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O) and cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6 H2O), were provided by Merk. Hydrofluoric Acid (HF, 77 %) was provided by ProtoKimica. Potassium hydroxide (KOH, 85 %) was provided by Alfa Aesar. Ultrapure water, H2O Milli-Q (18.2 MΩ cm−1) was used in all experiments. For electrode preparation: Nafion (5 %) and isopropyl alcohol (99 %) were provided by Sigma–Aldrich Chemical Co. 2.2 Synthesis of mesoporous carbonaceous support Carbonaceous porous materials as supports were prepared by the so-called soft template methodology [53]. Briefly, 8.63 g of F108 surfactant was dissolved in 180 mL of a 0.05 M aqueous NaOH solution (molar ratio H2O/F108 of 16.900) at 45 °C using an oil-bath, under magnetic stirring. The resulting pH of the solution was 12.7. Then, 6.16 g of TEOS was added to the F108 solution at 45 °C (molar ratio TEOS/F108 of 50). The mixture was kept at 45 °C for 18 h under magnetic stirring. After hydrolysis of TEOS, resorcinol and formaldehyde were added as carbon sources, the molar ratio in the resulting mixture was 50TEOS/1Surfactant/60Resorcinol/292Formaldehyde/16900 H2O. The reaction mixture was aged at 45 °C for 1 h and then at 67 °C for 48 h. The solid obtained was recovered by centrifugation at 9000 rpm at 25 °C, extensively washed with ultrapure water and dried at 90 °C for 12 h in a vacuum oven. The hybrid SiO2-resin powder was pyrolyzed at 900 °C for 3 h in a horizontal oven under N2 atmosphere using a flow rate of 100 mL min−1 and a heating rate of 2 °C min−1. The SiO2 phase was eliminated from the resulting composite, SiO2-carbonaceous powder, by etching with a 9 wt % HF solution, contact time of 24 h. The procedure was repeated twice with fresh HF solution. Finally, the obtained material was extensively washed with ultrapure H2O until reaching a pH of 7 and finally dried at 90 °C overnight. The carbonaceous powder was named as MC. 2.3 Catalysts preparation: dispersion of mixed Ni and Co oxides on mesoporous carbonaceous materials The mesoporous carbonaceous support (MC) was impregnated with (Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O and Co(NO3)2·6 H2O) salts as precursors for Ni and Co, through using the incipient wetness impregnation methodology, a total nominal loading of 20 wt % in Ni + Co was used. In order to evaluate the formation of a spinel-like NiCo2O4 phase, a nominal molar ratio between Co and Ni of 2 was stablished for the impregnation. In a typical preparation, the required amounts of nitrates (Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O and Co(NO3)2·6 H2O) were dissolved in ultrapure H2O, the total volume of the solution equals the total pore volume of the MC support. The obtained solution was slowly dropped into the MC while it was being mechanically stirred to allow proper contact between the powder and the solution. Then, the powder was dried at 90 °C for 24 h under vacuum. Finally, the sample was subjected to heat treatment in order to transform the metal precursors into the oxide phases at different temperatures and using different atmospheres: i) at 300 °C under static air atmosphere in a muffle oven (NiCo/MC-A300), ii) at 300 °C under O2 atmosphere (20 % O2 balanced with N2, total flow rate of 100 mL min−1) in a horizontal furnace (NiCo/MC-O300), iii) at 300 °C under N2 atmosphere (flow rate of 100 mL min−1) in a horizontal furnace (NiCo/MC-N300), and iv) at 700 °C under N2 (flow rate of 100 mL min−1) in a horizontal furnace (NiCo/MC-N700). In all cases, the heating rate was 2 °C min−1 with an isotherm at the target temperature for 3 h. For comparison, two monometallic catalysts were synthesized following the same procedure as described before and thermal treated under N2 at 300 and 700 ºC: (i) with only Co (Co/MC-N300 and Co/MC-N700), (ii) with only Ni (Ni/MC-N300 and Ni/MC-N700). 2.4 Physicochemical characterization The experimental metal loading was determined by atomic absorption analysis using a ThermoScientific ice 3000instrument. Metal oxides were dissolved in aqua regia overnight. The textural characteristics of the materials were analyzed by nitrogen adsorption-desorption at − 197 °C on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020. All samples were degassed at 100 °C for 1 h and then at 250 °C for 12 h prior to the adsorption-desorption measurements. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method was used to calculate the specific surface area (0.05–0.25 P/Po). The total pore volume (Vp) was taken as the cumulative isotherm up to P/P0 equal to 0.99. The total pore volume (Vp) was determined according to the Barrett, Joyner and Halenda (BJH) model, the mesoporous and microporous volumes were determined with the t-plot method. The pore size distribution was determined by using the Harkin-Jura model. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the materials were recorded to identify the crystal structure and crystallinity. XRD patterns were recorded using a Malvern-PANalytical Model Empyrean 2012, using Cu Kα1 radiation (λ = 1.541874 Å) operating at 45 kV and 40 mA; reflection transmission spinner with 4 s spin. The step was 0.02° with a time per step of 50 s. Scans were recorded at high angles of 2θ from 10° - 90°. Morphology, particle size, localization of metal-containing phases and elements distribution was determined by Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM and SEM-EDS) and High Transmission Electron Microscopy (HRTEM). SEM micrographs were obtained using a JEOL JSM-6490LV instrument with a LaB6 filament, at 20 kV accelerating voltage, the SEM instrument is equipped with an Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy (EDS) detector for element mapping. The samples were fixed on a graphite ribbon, and the surface was coated with gold (using a DENTON VACUUM Desk IV equipment). TEM micrographs were obtained in a Tecnai F20 Super Twin TMP instrument. The powders were embedded in a resin and sliced using an EM UC7 LEICA ultramicrotome. The surface chemical composition, oxidation states and chemical environment of the different elements in the materials were investigated using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (NAP-XPS) with a PHOIBOS 150 1D-DLD analyzer, using a monochromatic Al-Kα (1486.7 eV, 13 kV). The survey spectra were obtained using a pass energy of 86.36 eV with a step of 1 eV s−1 (five measurement cycles). The high-resolution spectra were recorded using a pass energy of 20 eV with steps of 0.1 eV s−1 (twenty measurement cycles). Charge compensation of 3 eV and 20 μA was used. The scale of the binding energy (BE) was calibrated by adjusting the adventitious carbon C–H to 284.6 eV. The XPS spectra were analyzed by CasaXPS software with signals corrected using a Tougaard background and asymmetric functions treated with a line shape SGL(p)T(k). The values of the Relative Sensitivity Factors (RSF), obtained from the Scofield database were: C 1 s (1.0), O 1 s (2.42744), Co 2p (12.5398), Ni 2p (13.3111). Restrictions were used for signal analysis: i) signals 1 s were processed by using the same FWHM; ii) signals 2p, with spin-orbit coupling 2p3/2 and 2p1/2, were analyzed taking the peaks for 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 with the same FWHM. Restrictions were imposed to the area ratio, the area of peaks associated with signals 2p1/2 being 0.5 of that of peaks associated with 2p3/2 signals. 2.5 Electrochemical characterization and electrocatalytic evaluation The electrochemical measurements are carried out on a Metrohm Autolab Potentiostat/Galvanostat type PGSTAT302N. The cell consists of a three-electrode array, with an Ag/AgCl reference electrode, a Platinum (Pt) electrode as counter electrode and a 5 mm diameter rotating ring disk glassy carbon electrode (RRDE) as working electrode. The electrolyte used was 0.1 M KOH. Prior to electrochemical analysis, the glassy carbon (GC) electrode was polished with 2000X sandpaper, nylon cloth with 5 µm alumina slurry, microfabric pads with 0.3 µm and 0.05 µm alumina slurry; then washed with plenty of ultrapure H2O and sonicated for 10 min. To prepare the catalyst ink, 5 mg of catalyst was dispersed in 700 µL of isopropanol, 300 µL of ultrapure H2O and 60 µL of Nafion (0.5 wt%) by sonication for 30 min and magnetic stirring at 1000 rpm for 1 h. The as-prepared catalyst ink (20 µL) was dropped onto the GC surface (3 mm diameter) using a micropipette and then dried under ambient conditions. Cyclic Voltammetry (CV) measurements were performed in a potential window from 0 to 2 V vs. RHE (reversible hydrogen electrode) at a scan rate of 50 mV s−1 and the solution of the electrolyte was saturated with either N2 or O2. The CV for ORR were performed in a potential window from 1.16 to 0.16 V vs. RHE at a scan rate of 5 mV s−1 and the solution of the electrolyte was saturated with either N2 or O2. Linear sweep voltammetry measurements for the Oxygen Evolution Reaction (LSV-OER) were performed when using N2 at a potential window of 1.2–2 V vs. RHE at a scan rate of 5 mV s−1, with a rotatory speed of 1600 rpm. Tafel slopes were derived from OER polarization curves. Linear sweep voltammetry measurements for the Oxygen Reduction Reaction (LSV-ORR) were performed when using O2 at a potential window of 1.2–0.2 V vs. RHE at a scan rate of 5 mV s−1, at different rotation speeds (400, 625, 900, 1225, 1600, 2025 and 2500 rpm), while the ring electrode was kept at 0.6 V Vs Ag/AgCl. The potentials measured with the EAg/AgCl reference electrode were converted to standard potentials of hydrogen (V vs. RHE) according to equation S1, in supplementary information. The overpotential (η) was calculated by using equations S2 and S3 for OER and ORR, respectively. The Koutecky-Levich plots (K-L plots) were employed to calculate the transferred number of electrons (n) per oxygen molecule in ORR according to equations S4 and S5. The electron transfer number (n) was also calculated by equation S6 and the percent of peroxides (H2O2) was calculated by the equation S7, both using the RRDE. All experiments were performed by triplicate to provide the reproducibility. In order to evaluate the performance of the obtained materials in this work with regard to those commercially available, two commercial noble-metal based heterogeneous catalysts were evaluated under similar reaction conditions in ORR and OER reactions. The Fuel Cell brand’s commercial 20 wt % platinum on Vulcan XC-72R (Pt/C) catalyst was used for the ORR and high surface area commercial iridium oxide (IrO2) was used for the OER. 2.6 Electrochemical evaluation in a prototype of Zn-air battery The evaluation of the cathode performance, build-up with selected catalysts, was carried out on a rechargeable Zn-Air home battery (30 mm × 30 mm × 25 mm) [54] using an Autolab PGSTAT302 N potentiostat/galvanostat. The cathode was prepared from NiCo/MC catalyst powders, which were dispersed on carbon cloth (CT Carbon Cloth without MPL - W0S1009) using an aerographer Talon-TG1108® (Pasche) to obtain a catalyst mass loading of 2.0 mg cm−2. For ink preparation, 1 mg of catalyst was added to 7 μL of Nafion (5 %) and 76 μL of isopropanol, mixed in ultrasonic bath for 1 h and then kept under magnetic stirring for 1 h. The air electrode consisted of a carbon paper (CP) water resistant (TGP-H-090, Toray), towards the air entrance it used a backing layer next to the cathode to avoid electrolyte leakage and a hollow sheet of titanium in the center as a current collector in contact with the cathode. The effective area of the cathode exposed to the air-electrolyte was 0.785 cm2. The anode was made of a previously polished Zn foil (0.38 mm thick, 1 cm2) placed in contact with a sheet of titanium as a current collector. Filter paper was used as separator and the electrolyte was a 6 M KOH aqueous solution, 0.2 M Zn(OAc)2 which was injected into the electrolyte compartment (1.4 mL). The charge and discharge polarization curves were performed at a current of 10−4 A s−1. The cut-off voltages of 0.1 V for discharge and 3.0 V for charge were established. The power density was calculated by using equation S8. The specific capacitance was determined with a full discharge of the ZAB at a current density of 6.4 mA cm−2 and calculated by using equation S9. Long-term galvanostatic tests were performed by cycling the ZAB for over 100 cycles at a current density of 5 mA cm−2, 10 min charge and 10 min discharge for each cycle. The round-trip efficiency was calculated from the charge-discharge cycle stability test at the 1st and 100th cycle by using equation S10. For electrochemical comparison in Zn-air battery, the commercial cloth GDE 4 mg cm−2 Pt-Ru from Fuel Cell Store was used. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural, structural, and morphological properties characterization The experimental loadings of Co and Ni are presented in Table 1. In general, the results show that the experimental metal loadings are higher than the nominal ones. Using a thermal treatment in air or O2 atmospheres, samples NiCo/MC-A300 and NiCo/MC-O300, led to higher loading for both metals, especially using air (59.9 wt %), indicating that combustion process might take place, reducing the amount of the carbonaceous support material. In the case of the samples treated under N2 atmosphere at 300 °C or 700 °C, the experimental metal loadings were also higher than the nominal ones, but lower than those presented in the oxidant atmospheres. Characterization by N2-physisorption ( Fig. 1A) demonstrated that a porous carbonaceous material as support (MC) was successfully obtained by using the soft-template methodology, based on the polymerization and reticulation of resorcinol-formaldehyde in a basic aqueous solution containing partially hydrolyzed TEOS and in presence of F108 surfactant [53]. After carbonization at 900 °C and silica etching, MC exhibits a type-IV isotherm (Fig. 1A) indicating that the material possesses mesoporosity but also microporosity because of the increase in the amount of N2 adsorbed at low P/P0 [55,56]. The MC powder exhibits a high specific surface area and pore volume (Table 1), with a wide pore size diameter distribution in the mesopore range. After simultaneous deposition of the metal precursors and their further thermal treatment to obtain the different NiCo/MC materials, pore structure and textural properties exhibit significant differences compared to the MC support (Fig. 1A and Table 1). The modifications in MC pore characteristics in terms of the isotherm-type and textural properties are dependent on the temperature and atmosphere used during the thermal treatment. The changes in isotherm and drop in specific surface area and pore volume are notable when using the impregnation method combined with air or oxygen atmospheres for thermal treatment. Both, NiCo/MC-A300 and NiCo/MC-O300, exhibit a type-I isotherm (Fig. 1A), which is characteristic of a microporous material, with a type-3 hysteresis loop indicating the formation of interparticle porosity and lower values of BET surface area than MC, without indication of mesoporous volume (Table 1), which means a collapse or significant blocking of the MC mesoporous structure. On the other hand, samples NiCo/MC-I-N300 and NiCo/MC-N700 exhibit a type-IV isotherm, with no significant changes in porosity as compared with MC support (Table 1). The XRD diffraction patterns at 2θ range between 10° and 70° are displayed in Fig. 1B. The XRD pattern at wide angle for MC shows the characteristic (002) and (100) reflexing peaks at 2θ of 25° and 45° for carbonaceous materials with a certain degree of graphitization (Fig. 1B) [57]. Mixed oxide NiCo2O4 spinel-like phase (ICSD: 69376) was identified on samples that underwent thermal treatment under air and O2 atmospheres at 300 °C: NiCo/MC-A300 and NiCo/MC-O300, being its formation more important in the air atmosphere. On the contrary, samples that were heat treated under N2 at 300 °C showed the formation of a physical mixture of NiO (ICSD:166118) and CoO (ICSD: 17013) while at 700 °C a physical mixture of metallic Ni (ICSD: 46090) and Co (ICSD: 622437) was obtained, instead of the NiCo2O4 spinel-like phase. This reaction behavior in N2 atmosphere, can be attributed to the fact that carbon is a reducing agent favoring the metal phase reduction during heat treatment under inert atmosphere at high temperatures [58]. Particle morphology and metals distribution was analyzed by SEM-EDS at micrometric scale. Micrographs of MC (Fig. S1) show amorphous particles with a random particle size, 3.01–132.07 µm, with an apparent rather smooth external surface. After deposition of metal precursors and thermal treatment, all materials exhibit amorphous MC support particles with no apparent change in particle size regarding MC (Fig. S2). After the formation of metal oxides under air or O2 atmospheres (Fig. S2A and S2B), the materials exhibit a rather rough surface with an apparent deposition of metal oxide particles on the external surface, while under N2 atmosphere either at 300 °C or 700 °C, samples NiCo/MC-N300 and NiCo/MC-N700 (Fig S2C and S2D), the external surface looks smooth without deposition of particles on the external surface of the support. The EDS analysis (Fig. S2) shows a homogeneous distribution of both, Ni and Co species in all NiCo/MC materials, regardless of the atmosphere and temperature of the thermal treatment. Further analysis about the localization and particle size of metal oxide particles at the nanometer size, was performed using HRTEM ( Fig. 2). Micrographs of sample NiCo/MC-O300 show evenly distributed nanoparticles of NiCo2O4 inside the pore structure of MC support mixed up with the decomposed support that also suffers the action of the oxidant atmosphere, with an average size of 4.93 ± 2.12 nm, in some areas bigger particles can also be observed with an average size of 9.37 ± 2.83 nm (Fig. 2A). Micrographs of sample NiCo/MC-A300 show NiCo2O4 particles with different morphologies and sizes (Fig. 2B), the images suggest the metal oxide particles are mainly located outside the grains of the MC support, indicating an unsuccessful control on localization and particle growth (average size 150.14 ± 20.84 nm). In the case of sample NiCo/MC-N300 (Fig. 2C), small nanoparticles of NiO and CoO are observed, uniformly distributed inside the pore structure with an average diameter of 2.55 ± 0.82 nm. Increasing the temperature of the heat treatment under N2 atmosphere at 700 °C, sample NiCo/MC-N700, allowed the formation and uniform distribution of metallic Ni and Co inside the pore structure of the MC support (Fig. 2D), but these nanoparticles exhibited a larger size than the metal oxides obtained at 300 °C, with an average diameter of 12.81 ± 3.29 nm. These results indicate that although the heat treatment under N2 does not favor the formation of spinel-like NiCo2O4, it improves the formation of nanoparticles inside the mesopores of the MC grains, regardless of the temperature of the heat treatment. According to the results of characterization presented to this point, the temperature and atmosphere during thermal treatment significantly impact the physical properties of the metal oxides or metallic phases. 3.2 Surface chemistry of materials The surface chemical composition, the different oxidation states, and the chemical environment of the chemical species at the surface were characterized by XPS. 3.2.1 MC support The XPS survey spectrum of MC shows the presence of C, O and Si, with a surface concentration of 93.26, 5.74 and 0.3 at%, respectively ( Table 2 and Fig S3A). The high-resolution XPS spectrum of C 1 s core level displays five different carbon functional groups (Fig. S4A and Table S2), with binging energies of: 284.6 eV assigned to CC sp2 (graphitic carbon); 284.8 eV for C-C sp3; 287.7 eV for C-O (in alcohol, phenols and ethers) and CO (in ketones); 289.2 eV for carboxyl, esters, lactone and other related carbons bonded to 2 and 3 heteroatoms (COOH or COOR (in carboxylic acids or esters)); the last signal at 290.7 may be attributed to π-π* satellite peak or to be associated with a more complex chemical environment with C atoms losing electronic density [59–61]. In the case of oxygen species, the high-resolution XPS spectrum of O 1 s core level displays four different signals (Fig. S4B and Table S2): at 531.4 eV for CO in ketones; at 532.5 eV for OH in phenol or aliphatic alcohols; at 533.6 eV for C-O-C in ethers, esters and anhydride, and at 534.4 eV in anhydride/C-OH in carboxylic acid and chemisorbed H2O [60–63]. 3.2.2 NiCo/MC materials The XPS survey spectrum in the different NiCo/MC materials are shown in Fig S3. As a first remark, there is a decrease in C and an increase in O surface concentration (Table 2), especially when samples were obtained using air or oxygen atmospheres during thermal treatment, NiCo/MC-A300 and NiCo/MC-O300. The increase in O at the surface is attributed to the formation of metal oxides at the surface. The changes in C and O surface concentration are less noticeable when the heat treatment was performed under N2 atmosphere, NiCo/MC-N300 and NiCo/MC-N700, regardless of the temperature. This result suggests that the use of the N2 atmosphere during thermal treatment reduced oxidation and loss of C and avoid in some extent the formation of highly oxidized species such as Co3+, favoring metallic Ni and Co at 700 °C as well as Ni2+ and Co2+ at 300 °C as will be discussed below, in agreement with the metallic phases identified by XRD. The high-resolution XPS spectra of C and O are presented in Figures S4C and S4D, and data are summarized in Table S3. The C 1 s core level displays four different most representative signals present in all catalysts, between 284.6 and 284.80 eV assigned to C-C sp3; at 285.3 eV and 285.65 for C-OH and C-O-C in alcohol, phenols and ethers; at 286.6 eV for CO in ketones and 288.75 eV for COOH/COOR. Other species are identified for the catalysts obtained when using air or O2 during the thermal treatment, NiCo/MC-A300 and NiCo/MC-O300 samples: at 285.2 eV and 285.7 eV assigned for C-H; at 288.4 eV for carbonate and π-π at 291.0 eV [40,64–66]. The O 1 s core level displays four different signals present in all catalysts. The signals between 528.5 and 529.6 eV are assigned to oxygen in the lattice corresponding to Ni-O and Co-O bonding [64,65]. The signal between 530.5 and 531.4 eV is assigned to oxygen on the surface corresponding to defects, contaminants, and a number of surface species including hydroxyls, chemisorbed oxygen, under-coordinated lattice oxygen; at 532.4 eV the signal is assigned to C-OH and at 533.1–535.5 eV is assigned to a multiplicity of physi- and chemi-sorbed water at or near the surface [67,68]. It is highlighted that in materials obtained in oxidizing atmospheres (NiCo/MC-A300 and NiCo/MC-O300), two signals are found around 530.50–531.40 eV that are assigned to oxygen species on the surface in different chemicals environments. The powder of NiCo/MC-N300 presented low contribution of oxygen species in the lattice, while the powder of NiCo/MC-N700 did not present contribution of oxygen species in the lattice (i.e, Ni-O and Co-O), this solid presented oxygen on the surface corresponding to under-coordinated lattice oxygen. For instance, the catalyst synthesized in inert atmosphere presented the lowest ratio of Olattice/Osurface (Table S3) indicating a greater contribution of oxygen species near the surface [40,64–66]. The high-resolution XPS spectra for Co and Ni in the different NiCo/MC materials are shown in Fig. 3. The surface concentration of Co and Ni species on the surface is higher for samples obtained when using air or O2 during the thermal treatment, compared to samples obtained under N2 atmosphere regardless of the temperature (Table 2). According to HRTEM characterization, tiny nanoparticles evenly distributed in the mesopore structure of the carbonaceous support were formed, thus the results of XPS might indicate a high and homogeneous distribution of cobalt and nickel species on the surface. As shown in Fig. 3A, the high-resolution XPS spectra of Co present the splitting of Co 2p into Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2. The chemical nature of cobalt species depends on the atmosphere during thermal treatment (Fig. 3 and Table S4). Two spin-doublets could be identified [69,70]: (i) NiCo/MC-O300: signals at 779.04 and 779.79 eV are assigned to Co3+ ions. The presence of Co3+ ions agree with the formation of spinel-like NiCo2O4. Nevertheless, the presence of these ions in two different chemical environments could indicate that defective NiCo2O4 or Co3+ ions are formed under O2-rich thermal treatment and stabilized on the surface of the powder. The signal at 780.76 eV is assigned to Co2+, indicating that cobalt is on the surface in different oxidation states and chemical environments, thus it is concluded that the small nanoparticles are exposing undercoordinated species on the surface. (ii) NiCo/MC-A300: signals at 779.16 eV assigned to Co3+, in agreement with the formation of spinel-like NiCo2O4, and at 780.37 eV assigned to Co2+. (iii) NiCo/MC-N300: signals at 780.06, 781.40 and 782.90 eV assigned to Co2+ in CoO and in different chemical environments. For instance, the small nanoparticles are exposing undercoordinated species on the surface. In this case, any signal indicating the presence of Co3+ was identified. (iv) NiCo/MC-N700, the spectrum is of low intensity and resolution, the signal at 778.5 eV is assigned to metallic Co [71], the signals at 780.3 and 781.7 eV are assigned to Co2+ in different chemical environments. Although XRD analysis showed the formation of metallic Co nanoparticles, the XPS indicates that there is surface oxidation of cobalt, mainly favoring Co2+ ions on the surface, which might also be attributed to small nanoparticles exposing undercoordinated species on the surface. In the case of nickel species, the Ni 2p spectra show the splitting into Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 (Fig. 3B and Table S4). Signals at 853.5 eV and 854.0 eV indicate the presence of Ni2+ species either in spinel-like NiCo2O4, case of samples NiCo/MC-O300 and NiCo/MC-A300, or NiO in the case of sample NiCo/MC-N300. The spectra also show signals at 854.2 eV and 856.2 eV indicating the presence of Ni3+ [70], and in the case of sample NiCo/MC-O300 an additional signal is observed which indicates that Ni3+ ions are in different chemical environments [40,66,72,73]. For instance, the thermal treatment under O2 atmosphere favors high oxidation states for both, nickel and cobalt, generating Co3+ and Ni3+ stabilized on the surface and in different chemical environments. The spectrum of NiCo/MC-N700 sample exhibit low intensity signals, thereby, the spectra could not be processed. The low intensity could be attributed to the high distribution of tiny particles inside the pore structure of the carbonaceous support. 3.3 Electrochemical characterization and activity for ORR and OER reactions The electrochemical characterization and activity of metal-free MC and NiCo/MC materials in ORR and OER reactions were initially evaluated by cyclic voltammetry (CV) in order to investigate the reduction and oxidation processes that could take place on the surface of the materials, and their stability under the reaction conditions (Fig S5), and the Linear Sweep Voltammetry (LSV) to determine the kinetic parameters of the materials as electrocatalysts ( Figs. 4 and 5, and gathered in Table 3). 3.3.1 Electrochemical characterization CV measurements in N2- and O2-saturated basic aqueous solutions show redox couple peaks (Ia: anodic peak and Ic: cathodic peak) for NiCo/MC-O300 and NiCo/MC-A300 (Fig. S5), due to the coexistence of nickel and cobalt species, the redox couple Ia/Ic at ∼1.48 V/∼1.23 V is associated to the Ni(II)/Ni(III), Co(II)/Co(III) and Co(III)/Co(IV), attributed to the Faradaic redox reactions, followed by their reactions in basic aqueous medium (Eqs. 3–4) [40,74–80]. (3) NiCo 2 O 4 + OH − + H 2 O ↔ NiOOH + 2 CoOOH + e − (4) CoOOH + OH − ↔ Co O 2 + H 2 O + e − These results are consistent with the XRD and XPS data of NiCo/MC-O300 and NiCo/MC-A300 materials, which showed the formation of the NiCo2O4 mixed oxide in the samples with the presence of Ni2+, Ni3+, Co2+, and Co3+ species on their surface. On the contrary, the catalysts NiCo/MC-N300 and NiCo/MC-N700 do not show oxidation peaks in saturated N2 basic aqueous solution, while in saturated O2 solution a clear redox couple peak Ia/Ic is observed (Fig. S5). The redox potential of this redox couple, Ia/Ic at approximately 1.42 V/1.11 V, is associated to the Ni(II)/Ni(III) and Co(II)/Co(III) attributed to the Faradaic redox reaction, and the reactions in basic aqueous medium (Eqs. 5–8) [81–85]. These results could be explained by the different chemical nature of nickel and cobalt species on the surface of the different materials. The NiCo/MC-N300 showed NiO and CoO phases, as well as the species of Ni2+, Ni3+, and Co2+ on the surface, according to the XRD and XPS data; in contrast, the NiCo/MC-N700 showed metallic Ni and Co phases according to the XRD results and Co0 and Co2+ species on the surface, according to XPS data. (5) Ni ( OH ) 2 + OH − ↔ NiOOH + H 2 O + e − (6) Co ( OH ) 2 + OH − ↔ CoOOH + H 2 O + e − Or (7) NiO + OH − ↔ NiOOH + e − (8) CoO + OH − ↔ CoOOH + e − 3.3.2 Electrocatalytic activity for ORR and OER LSV measurements (Fig. 4) show that all materials, including metal-free MC, have activity against OER because with all materials a current density of 10 mA cm−2 (J 10 ) was reached (Fig. 4 A and Table 3). The NiCo/MC-N700 presented the lowest overpotential (η) of 474 mV at J 10 , which is lower than for MC and all other NiCo/MC materials, NiCo/MC-O300 (508 mV), NiCo/MC-A300 (511 mV), NiCo/MC-N300 (549 mV) and MC (551 mV). The Tafel slope was used to compare the reaction kinetics performance of the electrocatalysts (Fig. 4B and Table 3). From the lowest to the highest value, the electrocatalysts displayed the following order of activity in OER according to the value of the Tafel slope: NiCo/MC-A300 (92 mV dec−1) < NiCo/MC-N700 (94 mV dec−1) < NiCo/MC-O300 (98 mV dec−1) < NiCo/MC-N300 (150 mV dec−1) < MC (257 mV dec−1). The decrease of the Tafel slope of the NiCo/MC catalysts in comparation with metal-free MC catalyst, is an indication that nickel and cobalt species on the surface favor an effective charge-transfer process on MC support and are active materials for OER reaction i.e. activate OH- transformation to O2 evolution. It is important to highlight that unlike what is discussed in the literature, where the active sites for the OER are attributed to Ni3+ and Co3+ species [41,80,86], there is no clear relationship with the activity in the OER and the electrocatalysts with greater presence on the surface of Ni3+ and Co3+ species, NiCo/MC-O300 and NiCo/MC-A300, where the surface atomic ratio for Ni3+/Ni2+ is 1.69 and 3.57% and the Co3+/Co2+ is 0.72 and 1.04%, respectively. Instead, the metallic Ni and Co particles, sample NiCo/MC-N700, as well as spinel-like NiCo2O4, samples NiCo/MC-A300 and NiCo/MC-O300, and mixed oxides NiO and CoO, sample NiCo/MC-N300, are all potential candidates as active phases for an efficient transformation of OH- ions into O2. The CV measurements in the ORR potential window, in a saturated N2 solution do not show reduction peaks (Ic ORR) for any of the catalysts, the peaks obtained when performing the CVs in a saturated O2 aqueous solution correspond to the oxygen reduction reaction, indicating that all materials are stable under O2 atmosphere in the potential window evaluated (Fig. 5). The CV measurements for metal-free MC carbonaceous material show a reduction peak (Ic ORR) at 0.77 V during the negative potential scan. This suggests the irreversible reduction of O2 and therefore the presence of surface chemical species on MC that allow the adsorption and activation of the O2 molecule (Fig. 5A). In the case of NiCo/MC-A300 and NiCo/MC-O300 materials, both presented a reduction peak (Ic ORR) at 0.61 and 0.69 V respectively (Fig. 5A), which implies the presence of active sites for the ORR reaction, but these materials present a high overpotential compared to the catalysts obtained under N2 atmosphere, which indicates a low activity towards the ORR reaction. On the other hand, the CVs of NiCo/MC-N300 and NiCo/MC-N700 materials exhibit a reduction peak (Ic ORR) at 0.77 and 0.78 V respectively, with high current density, showing that there are active sites accessible for the ORR reaction (Fig. 5A). The LSV curves for ORR were obtained on a rotating ring disk electrode (RRDE) to eliminate the mass transport effect and to investigate on the activity of the electrocatalysts (Fig. 5B). Polarization curves (Fig. 5B and Table 3) show that metal-free MC and NiCo/MC-N300, NiCo/MC-N700 materials exhibit the best electrocatalytic performance in ORR in comparison with NiCo/MC-O300 and NiCo/MC-A300, based on the values of the half-wave potential (E1/2) and the limiting current densities (JL) (Table 3). The NiCo/MC-N300 and NiCo/MC-N700 electrocatalysts exhibit the highest limiting current density, JL of −3.47 and −3.60 mA cm−2 respectively, among the materials studied and a comparable onset potential, E onset of 0.81 and 0.84 V, and half-wave potential, E 1/2 of 0.74 and 0.77 V respectively, as for metal free MC (E onset = 0.83 V; E 1/2 = 0.73 V and JL = −3.39 mA cm−2). This result suggests that metal-free MC, NiCo/MC-N300 and NiCo/MC-N700 presented high density of active sites for activating O2 to OH-. Further analysis on the kinetics of the different materials for ORR was performed by using the RRDE technique at different rotation rates in the range 400–2500 rpm and Koutecky-Levich K-L plots) were employed to calculate the transferred number of electrons (n) per oxygen molecule in ORR according to equation S4 (eq. S4) in the zone of the mixed control (Fig. S6 and Table 3). Also, the electron transfer number (n) was calculated by equation S6 (eq. S6) using the RRDE and is presented in Fig. 5 C and Table 3. The percent of peroxides (H2O2) was calculated by the equation S7 (Fig. 5D and Table 3). The ORR reaction can proceed through the 2 or 4 electron reaction pathways (Table S1), when the ORR takes place through the 4-electron transfer process, I r = 0, the apparent number is 4, when the ORR is a pure 2-electron transfer process, I r = I d N, gives an apparent number of 2. In this way, the 4-electron reaction is more effective for ORR, in which there is almost no generation of HO2 − [35]. The metal-free MC shows an electron transfer (n) of 2⊡1 by K-L plots (eq S4) and average n of 2.9 by using RRDE (eq S6). These results suggest that O2 proper adsorption and activation is not occurring, and the O2 molecules adsorption and activation could have taken place through different active sites. In this way, the production of peroxides (H2O2) is high reaching 37.5%, indicating a mechanism pathway of 2 electrons. The number of electrons transferred for all the NiCo/MC catalysts was ∼4, using both equations (eqs. S4 and S6), indicating that these catalysts favor the highly efficient direct four-electron reaction pathway, and therefore the adsorption and activation could take place at a single active site where oxygen molecules are directly adsorbed, activated and reduced to OH- [87]. The NiCo/MC-N300 and NiCo/MC-N700 presented the most remarkable ORR activity, with high CV-ORR peak, high E1/2, with an electron transfer of 4, and low production of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) reaching 9.8 and 10.6, respectively (Table 3). Their good electrocatalytic activity for the ORR may be associated with the presence of a high surface atomic concentration of Co2+ species in different chemical environments (Fig. 3). This result supports those discussed in the literature, where the Co2+ species are reported as the most active sites for the ORR reaction [42,80,86]. For comparison, monometallic Co/MC-N300, Co/MC-N700, Ni/MC-N300 and Ni/MC-N700 were also evaluated under comparable experimental conditions in ORR and OER reactions (Figs. 4 and 5, and Table 3). The results evidenced that Ni/MC-300 and Ni/MC-700 showed comparable activity in OER and in some extent similar to the activity exhibited by NiCo/MC-N700 catalyst (Fig. 4). However, their Tafel slope is higher with values above 145 mV dec−1 (Table 3). In ORR their catalytic performance was lower than with other catalysts, including monometallic Co/MC (Fig. 5), with low CV-ORR peak (Fig. 5), an electron transfer number of 2, and high production of hydrogen peroxide (Table 3). On the other hand, the Co/MC-N300 and Co/MC-N700 exhibited lower activity in OER when compared to other catalysts, including those with monometallic nickel (Fig. 4), with high overpotential greater than 545 mV at J10 and high Tafel slope greater than 226 mV dec−1 (Table 3). Nevertheless, in ORR the Co/MC-N300 showed the highest activity among the studied materials (CV-ORR peak at 0.8 V; E onset = 0.85 V; E 1/2 = 0.75 V; JL = −5.56 mA cm−2; electron transfer number of 4, and low H2O2 production (5.0%)) (Table 3). For instance, the results indicate that combining both, Ni and Co, an improved catalytic performance is reached leading to a bifunctional catalyst with nickel species enhancing OER performance and cobalt species enhancing ORR activity. Finally, commercial Pt/C and IrO2 were also evaluated (Figs. 4 and 5, and Table 3). In OER the NiCo/MC-N700 showed a comparable activity to that obtained with IrO2 although in ORR the performance was lower than that obtained with Pt/C. Up to this point, to identify the best electrocatalyst in terms of ORR and OER performance, two criteria were considered: i) ΔE, defined as the potential difference between Ej10 and E1/2 (Fig. S8A and Table 3), and ii) the number of electron transferred during ORR, being the 4 electron pathway the most efficient [88,89]. The NiCo/MC-N700, NiCo/MC-N300 and metal-free MC presented the most remarkable bifunctional activities, with values of ΔE of 0.93, 1.04 and 1.05 V, respectively (Table 3 and Fig S8A). It is highlighted that for ORR, the NiCo/MC-N700 and NiCo/MC-N300 catalysts presented an electron transfer number of 4, indicating that ORR takes place through the highly efficient four-electron direct reaction pathway, favouring enhanced kinetics. In addition, a substantial decrease in the H2O2 production is obtained when using Ni and Co species through modification of the synthesis temperature and atmosphere. Finally, from an operating point of view of the preparation conditions the NiCo/MC-N300 is obtained at lower temperature. A comparison between OER at potential at current density of 10 mA cm−2 (EJ10) and ORR at half-wave potential (E1/2) for NiCo/MC-N300, NiCo/MC-N700 and various catalysts in the star-of-art is presented in Table S5 and Fig S8B. The results are in line with those reported in the literature but are depending on the physicochemical properties of the material, the NiCo/MC-N300 and NiCo/MC-N700 show a similar electrocatalytic behaviour with those reported for ORR while the NiCo/MC-N700 shows similar performance for OER with than the most active reported catalysts. A correlation of the physicochemical properties and electrocatalytic activity is presented in Fig. 6. The improved electrocatalytic activity of the NiCo/MC-N300 could be associated to a combination of physical and chemical properties (Fig. 6): i) the high specific surface area (SBET 888 m2 g−1) and pore volume (1.4 cm3 g−1) dominated mainly by a mesoporous structure (Vmeso 1.2 cm3 g−1) which favor a rather homogeneous distribution of metal oxide nanoparticles dispersing the active sites and allowing at the same time accessibility of the O2 and OH- species to and from the active sites (Fig. S9); ii) During the thermal treatment at 300 °C under N2, the synthesis of small nanoparticles of NiO-CoO (2.55 ± 0.82 nm), well distributed inside the mesopores of the MC grains (Fig. 6 and Fig. S10), small nanoparticles might favor a highly active surface because of the formation of undercoordinated metal ions, Co2+ and Ni2+, in different chemical environments (Fig. 6 and S11, S12, S13), increasing dispersion of active sites for anchoring and activating O2 and OH- ions. As observed in Fig. 6, the structural phase and particle size, as well as the surface atomic concentration of Co2+ ions influence activity in both the ORR and OER reactions. 3.4 Electrochemical performance in a Zn-air battery For NiCo/MC-N300 and NiCo/MC-N700 that showed the best electrochemical performances for ORR and OER reactions according to the above electrochemical evaluation, a proof-of-concept application was designed. To this purpose, an air-breathing home-made aqueous Zn-air battery was assembled as already reported [54], to evaluate the electrochemical performance of these electrocatalysts under practical operation conditions, and to compare it with that exhibited by a commercial Pt-Ru/C catalyst ( Fig. 7A and Table 4). The charge and discharge polarization curves are shown in Fig. 7B. The electrocatalysts exhibited a comparable electrocatalytic behavior for the discharge process but a significant difference in the charging process, given that at a current density of 24 mA cm−2, the measured potential for the charging process is 1.8 V with NiCo/MC-N700 while for the NiCo/MC-N300 material reached 2.2 V. The power density curves are shown in Fig. 7 C, with the NiCo/MC-N700 material presenting the highest peak power density of 56.78 mW cm−2 at a current density of 72 mA cm−2, which is close to the Pt-Ru/C noble metal-based catalyst which exhibits a peak power density of 68.11 mW cm−2 at a current density of 77.52 mA cm−2. On the other hand, the NiCo/MC-N300 material presented a peak of power density of 36.25 mW cm−2 at a current density of 58 mA cm−2. The specific capacities (Fig. 7D) of the evaluated materials, NiCo/MC-N300 and NiCo/MC-N700, are 766.18 and 703.80 mAh gZn −1, respectively, which are close to the theoretical value of 820 mA gZn −1. Nevertheless, these values of specific capacity are lower than for the noble metal-based catalyst with a specific capacity of 907.98 mAh gZn −1. To estimate the stability of the materials, the long-term galvanostatic test was done during 10 min charge and 10 min discharge at 5 mA cm −2 for over 100 cycles (Fig. 7E and Table 4). When evaluating the voltage gap for the first cycle, values of 0.99 and 0.89 V were obtained, with a percentage of round-trip efficiency of 54.35 and 56.58 %, respectively. In the 100th cycle, the voltage gap values were 1.73 and 1.87 V, generating a percentage of round-trip efficiency of 19.31 and 10.32 % for NiCo/MC-N300 and NiCo/MC-N700, respectively. For comparison purposes, the catalyst based on noble metals (Pt-Ru/C) presented a voltage gap value of 0.64 V for a percentage of round-trip efficiency of 66.76 % for the first cycle and a voltage gap value of 0.83 V for a percentage of round-trip efficiency of 58.50 % for the 100th cycle. Recent published research using similar electrocatalysts in Zn-air batteries is shown Table S6. The materials NiCo/MC-N300 and NiCo/MC-N700 evaluated in the cathode of a home-made Zn-air battery show promising performance. These materials showed activity in the ZAB, with a round-trip efficiency in the 1st cycle ∼55.4±1.2 %, a significant deactivation is evidenced during cycling, given that round-trip efficiency of 100th cycle is less than 19 %. The deactivation of the material may be due to physicochemical transformations of the active species, or of the carbon catalytic support, as well as a lack in mechanical stability of the final electrode assembles. To give a clearer explanation of the deactivation phenomenon, it is necessary to perform additional physicochemical analyses with post-mortem electrocatalysts and the electrode itself. 4 Conclusions The fine-tunning of the physical and chemical properties of supported heterogeneous catalysts to mediate the interactions between the active sites and O2/OH- species is of fundamental relevance to find bifunctional electrocatalysts for ORR and OER reactions during the operation of a cathode in a Zn-air battery. In this work it was attempted to develop a catalyst for this cathode using a mesoporous carbon with high surface area and pore volume as support of Co and Ni species, by transformation of their nitrate salts under thermal treatment under different atmospheres. It is found that the structure, localization, particle size and surface atomic concentration of the different species of cobalt and nickel formed, can be controlled by the temperature and type of atmosphere during the thermal treatment. The use of an oxidizing atmosphere combined with heat treatment at 300 °C favors the formation of spinel-like NiCo2O4 mixed oxide, which exposed oxidized species of Ni2+, Ni3+, Co2+, Co3+ on the surface, but also clogging of the pore structure generating particles inside and outside the porous structure of the MC support, leading to the formation of large nanoparticles with a wide particle size distribution. Instead, the use of an inert atmosphere as N2, allowed the formation of smaller nanoparticles confined inside the pore structure of the MC support, with a structure that depends on the temperature of the thermal treatment. For instance, a mixture of metal oxide nanoparticles of NiO and CoO are formed at 300 °C (NiCo/MC-N300), and metallic species of Ni and Co at 700 °C (NiCo/MC-N700), in both materials the surface of the nanoparticles is enriched in Co2+ species, but only detectable presence of Ni2+ species for the material developed at 300 °C, were found. The materials obtained under N2 atmosphere exhibited better electrocatalytic performance than the materials obtained under air or O2 atmosphere, with bifunctional activity for ORR and OER reactions. The results indicated that the transformation of cobalt and nickel salt precursors under N2 atmosphere produces a simultaneous confinement of small nanoparticles inside the mesopores of the carbonaceous support, favoring at the surface Co2+ and Ni2+ species, especially undercoordinated Co2+ in different chemical environments. This effect, combined with a high surface area and pore volume of the support, allowed interaction of O2 species with the active sites leading to a proper adsorption and activation for its transformation into OH- during ORR, while also providing high activity for adsorbing and activating OH- to O2 during OER. Evaluation of potential application in a homemade rechargeable Zn-air battery, the cathodes fabricated with the NiCo/MC-N300 and NiCo/MC-N700 exhibited respectively, specific-capacity of 766.18 mA h g−1 and 703.80 mA h g−1 and a peak power density of 36.25 mW cm−2 and 56.78 mW cm−2; a performance that is close to the obtained with noble metal-based cathode using Pt-Ru. Both cathodes showed a round-trip efficiency in the 1st cycle of ∼55.4±1.2 %, with a significant deactivation evidenced during cycling. Work to try to improve the efficiency and stability of these assembles is under way. coredata.dc:description: This work aims to study the effect of different atmospheres and temperatures in the synthesis of a bifunctional electrocatalyst for ORR and OER reactions in the cathode of a Zn-air battery, using a carbonaceous support for dispersing Ni and Co species. At 300 °C, NiCo2O4 with a size of 4.93 nm under O2 and 150.14 nm using air, were obtained. These materials exhibited low specific surface area and pore volume and failed to show bifunctional activity. Instead, the simultaneous dispersion of NiO and CoO nanoparticles, with a size of 2.55 nm was achieved at 300 °C under N2 (NiCo/MC-N300), leading to a surface enrichment in Co2+ and Ni2+ species, while Ni and Co nanoparticles, 12.81 nm, were obtained at 700 °C under N2 (NiCo/MC-N700). These catalysts exhibited high specific surface area and pore volume, and bifunctional electrochemical activity; as well as high specific-capacity in a home-made Zn-air battery.

coredata.dc:title: Nanoparticles of NiO and CoO simultaneously dispersed on a mesoporous carbonaceous support as bifunctional electrocatalysts for ORR and OER reactions and Zn-air battery performance
